tossups.question: A character in this novel is haunted after seeing a French boy’s arm hanging from a tree. Another character in this novel is instructed not to reveal her first name to patients while working as a nurse under the strict Sister Drummond. After breaking a vase, a character in this novel undresses to retrieve the pieces from a fountain. This novel’s ending was revealed to be (*) fictional, as a way for an elderly writer to make up for actions she did as a 13-year old with the help of her cousin Lola. After accidentally delivering a sexually explicit letter, a character in this novel has a sexual encounter with Cecilia Tallis in a library. For 10 points, name this novel in which Briony falsely accuses Robbie Turner of rape, written by Ian McEwan.

Large substituent molecules will favor reactions with this characteristic due to the Thorpe-Ingold effect. It doesn’t involve protecting groups, but silicon tethers are inert molecules that artificially drive reactions to temporarily possess this characteristic. The rate constant for reactions with this characteristic appears in the numerator when calculating the effective molarity. Reactions with this characteristic experience a significant rate (*) acceleration relative to their counterparts due to the proximity effect. Cyclizations and rearrangements are two types of reactions with this characteristic. For 10 points, name this characteristic of reactions that are limited to altering the structure of a single molecule.
tossups.answer: intramolecular reactions [accept unimolecular; do not accept “intermolecular”; prompt on cyclization,  cycloaddition, rearrangement, condensation, ring closure, or ring expansion/growth with “those reaction have what general characteristic?”]

tossups.question: Cartoons in favor of this practice exhorted people to vote for a Unionist government with the tagline “the slacker must not rule”. A mayor who was an opponent of this practice, Camillien Houde, was declared a public threat and detained in Camp Petawawa. “Zombies” resulting from this practice were ridiculed for not going overseas until the passage of Bill 80. Henri (*) Bourassa railed against this practice, leading to the Easter Riots. Robert Borden tried to form a unified government with Wilfrid Laurier to implement this practice after the Battle of the Somme. For 10 points, name this practice which caused two namesake “crises” in Canada in 1917 and 1944.
tossups.answer: conscription [prompt on anything mentioning mandatory military service; prompt on the draft]

tossups.question: A Michael Frede paper argues that Aristotle lacked this concept and instead traced the origin of this concept to Epictetus. According to Duns Scotus, this concept is possible due to the division of units of time into "instants of nature." St. Evodius related this concept to sin and the power of God in a letter to St. Augustine, who had himself used this concept to explain the compatibility of evil with the (*) foreknowledge of God. In De Rerum Natura, Lucretius explained this concept with the clinamen, or the swerve of atoms which break a causal chain of events. For 10 points, name this concept which is opposed by determinism, the idea that you can choose your own actions.

A novel from this country opens with a woman shooting her husband, then going for coffee. The Dry Heart was written by an author from this country who recounted her childhood in Family Lexicon. In a novel from this country, a character encounters kids who believe aliens are trying to communicate through him. That character, Silas Flannery, is falsely given credit for books by (*) Ermes Marana.  After discovering his book is defective, the narrator of a novel from this country meets Ludmilla, a fellow reader. The chapters of that novel from this country alternate between the first chapters of ten fictional books and a frame story narrated in the second person. For 10 points, name this home country of Natalia Ginzburg and the author of If on a Winter’s Night a Traveler, Italo Calvino.

Fine particles with this behavior are used as enhancers for x-ray imaging, and have been used to map the right ventricle of the human heart. In one model, this phenomenon occurs when the product of the Stoner parameter and the density of states at the Fermi level is greater than one. A double-exchange mechanism results in materials possessing this behavior, such as (*) Heusler alloys. Discrete current pulses are observed as finite jumps on the J vs. H curve of a material exhibiting this behavior in the Barkhausen effect. This behavior is lost as materials exceed the Curie temperature. For 10 points, name this behavior in which parallel domain alignment results in substances with permanent magnetism.

A coup against this leader failed after he sent the army division meant to attack him to go harvest maize instead. Intellectuals under this leader claimed that the Tartaria Tables depicted the first alphabet to support their theories of “protochronism”. The purge of Ana Pauker and the “Muscovite” faction brought this man to power. This man declared “the fetus is the property of the entire society” in his Decree 770, which (*) banned contraception. Thousands of orphans were crammed into orphanages such as Cighid during this man’s reign. This man laid out his political philosophy in the July Theses. Cries of “Timisoara!” overshadowed a speech by this leader, after which he and his wife Elena were killed on Christmas on live TV. For 10 points, name this Romanian dictator.

In an East Nigerian folk tale, a bush rat named Oyot boils himself alive after Emiong, who is one of these creatures, lies to him about how he makes his soup so delicious. In Book 4 of Ovid’s Metamorphoses, Bacchus turns the daughters of Minyas into these animals when they refuse to participate in a festival dedicated to him. In the (*) Popol Vuh, a messenger that resembles this animal negotiates a deal in which mankind offers their armpits and waists in exchange for fire. The Mayan god of death, Camazotz, takes the form of this animal and lends his name to a creature that decapitates Hunahpu when he travels to Xibalba with his twin brother. For ten points, name these flying mammals that are often associated with vampires.

Emile Zola described one painting by this artist as “anti-artistic” due to the “exactitude of copying” it exhibited. After that painting was rejected by the Salon, this artist made another version of the same work only to have it described as ‘vulgar’. In another painting, this artist depicted his brother looking over a balcony with an orange chair behind him, showing the view of the title Young Man at a (*) Window. In another work by this artist, a bottle of wine sits on the floor beside the three shirtless title figures. In this artist’s best-known painting, subjects hold umbrellas over their heads due to the title weather phenomenon, one of which is shared by the central couple. For 10 points, name this artist of The Floor Scrapers and Paris Street; Rainy Day.

A Javanese kind of these objects made from Iket fabric is called a blangkon and sometimes has a knot of leather hanging from their backs. The Albanian qeleshe type of these objects comes in flat topped, hemispherical, and oval shaped varieties. One type of these objects originating from Assam is named jaapi, in reference to it being made of tightly wound bamboo. In East Africa, the kofia variety of these objects is worn, which is related to the (*) kufi variety of these objects from west Africa. The Mevlevi order frequently wears camel hair examples of these objects known as dikke. A red one of these objects shaped like a truncated cone is commonly worn with a tassel in North Africa. For 10 points, name these articles of clothing, an example of which is the fez.
tossups.answer: hats [or caps; or head coverings; headwear; headgear; headpiece; etc]

bonuses.leadin: This dance troupe’s performances and popularity were extensively analyzed in Siegfried Kracauer’s The Mass Ornament. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Follies [accept Ziegfield’s Follies; prompt on vaudeville (shows)]
parts: Name this pioneering dance troupe, which quickly became one of the most popular in Europe after being founded by their namesake theatre director in the 1890s. This dance troupe’s signature routines of high step “Tap and Kick” dancing would later become known as “precision dancing”.

The Tiller Girls’ long lines of high stepping dancers directly inspired this modern-day precision dance company best-known for performing in New York’s Radio City Music Hall and for their Christmas Spectacular.

The Rockettes were created after their founder watched a Tiller Girls performance in one of these revues named for Florenz Ziegfield. A 1971 Sondheim musical named for these multi-act performances includes the songs “Losing my Mind” and “Broadway Baby”.

bonuses.leadin: This culture’s art depicts the “long-nosed god” motif in masks and ornaments made out of shells. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Crow Creek Massacre [or Crow Creek Site]
parts: Name this culture characterized by the Southeastern Ceremonial Complex with sites such as Cahokia.
Cahokia contains this mound, the largest pyramid north of Mesoamerica. This mound was built by workers who transported baskets full of dirt and clay from nearby sites to the mound.

This South Dakota site saw a massacre of at least 486 people sometime during the mid-1300s. Archaeological research shows evidence of scalping, broken teeth, cut tongues, and other signs of mutilation at this site.

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about compounds with square planar geometry. For 10 points each:
parts: During this industrial process, an iridium catalyst with square planar geometry is used to facilitate the binding of carbon monoxide molecules to methanol.

One of the most commonly cited examples of a compound with square planar geometry is the tetrafluoride of this fifth-heaviest noble gas. Neil Bartlett pioneered the chemistry of compounds based on this noble gas by reacting its hexaplatinate.
This other compound with square planar geometry has a central rhodium atom surrounded by three tri-phenyl-phosphine ligands, and one chlorine atom. It is a red-brown powder at room temperature.

bonuses.leadin: One work in this medium, Koyaanisqatsi, was accompanied by music composed by Philip Glass. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Aaron Copland [the piece is Fanfare for the Common Man]
parts: Name this medium for which John Williams has composed many scores.

This composer wrote scores for film adaptations of the John Steinbeck books Of Mice and Men and The Red Pony. A Henry Wallace speech inspired an orchestral work by this man that opens with notes from the timpani, bass drum, and tam-tam before trumpets play the ascending notes F - B-flat - F.

This composer has scored every Paul Thomas Anderson film since There Will Be Blood. He plays the ondes Martenot on “Jigsaw Falling Into Place” and “How to Disappear Completely,” songs by a band he and his brother Colin are members of.

bonuses.leadin: A group in this country led by Comrade Evaristo demanded the release of activist Lori Berenson during a 1997 hostage crisis. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Alberto Fujimori [accept Alberto Fujimori Fujimori; yes, his middle name is Fujimori]
Vladimiro Montesinos [accept Vladimiro Lenin Ilich Montesinos Torres]
parts: Name this country where the Tupac Amaru Revolutionary Movement took control of a Japanese embassy in Lima.
This president of Peru ordered Operation Chavin de Huantar to flush out the terrorists. This man’s Grupo Colina death squad carried out extrajudicial killings against Shining Path.
This leader of Fujimori’s SIN secret police was videotaped bribing TV stations to not broadcast coverage of Fujimori’s political opponents.

bonuses.leadin: This author's first novel was a novelization of the life of the privateer Henry Morgan. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this author of Cup of Gold, who also wrote about the Joad family in The Grapes of Wrath.

This other Steinbeck novel follows the lives of a group of "paisanos" who live in the title area north of Monterrey, California. This novel ends with Pilon and Pablo allowing Danny's home to burn down after Danny's funeral.

The preface to Tortilla Flat describes Danny as analogous to this figure. At the time of Steinbeck's death, he was writing a psychological version of the myths of this figure based on the Westminster Manuscript.

bonuses.leadin: In one essay titled "Leader", this person's resurrection is satirically described as causing Russia to cede portions of Siberia and Mongolia deciding to join China. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Mao Zedong (the essay "Leader" is from the book China in Ten Words by Yu Hua)
parts: Name this leader, whose abandonment of He Zizhen and marriage to Jiang Qing was criticized in the Ding Ling essay "Thoughts on March 8," an act also depicted in an Anchee Min novel titled for Becoming his wife.

Maos' phrase "serve the people" became the title for a novel by this Chinese satirist, which describes the death of Comrade Zhang Side. This author's other novels include one depicting an AIDS outbreak titled Dream of Ding Village.

This other Chinese novelist received criticism for hand copying Mao's speech at the Yan'an Forum during its 70th anniversary celebration. This Nobel Prize-winner wrote The Republic of Wine and Red Sorghum Clan.

bonuses.leadin: Artists from Titian’s studio were commissioned to create the more than 250 intricate woodcuts that serve as illustrations for this text. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: De Humani Corpus Fabrica libri septem [or The Seven Books on the Structure of the Human Body; prompt on partial answers]
parts: Name this pioneering work of Renaissance anatomy. This text by Andreas Vesalius is an extensive compilation of his lectures and human dissections that helped disprove the flawed theories of Galen of Pergamon.

Vesalius’ Fabrica was compiled from the lectures he gave while teaching the University of Padua, which contains the oldest anatomical theatre in Europe. The University of Padua itself is the second oldest university in Europe, behind the university in this other Italian city.

This Polish polymath briefly studied medicine at the University of Padua in the early 1500s. He would later achieve more renown for championing heliocentrism in books like On the Revolutions of the Celestial Spheres.

bonuses.leadin: In 2015, the Court of Appeals in Mombasa ruled that forced anal exams for people accused of this crime were unconstitutional. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: homosexuality [accept obvious equivalents such as gay sex or same sex relations; prompt on sodomy]
HIV clinics [accept AIDS clinics; accept any answer about doctors who treat HIV or AIDS; prompt on partial answers]
parts: Name this crime, which, in 2018 was legalized in India, reversing an 1800s era colonial law which established this crime.
Mombasa Court of Appeals is located in this country, which in 2019 did not overturn colonial era laws outlawing homosexuality. This country's supreme court is located in the city of Nairobi.

In the town of Mtwapa, a false rumor that two men planned to marry sparked a protest that involved the destruction of one of these facilities. In Tanzania, these facilities have been expelled because of accusations that they "promote a homosexual lifestyle."

bonuses.leadin: At the end of The Blue Kite, a boy nicknamed "iron head" gazes at the title object while his stepfather is victimized during this event. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: People's Republic of China [or Zhongguo; do NOT accept or prompt on "Republic of China" or "Taiwan"]
parts: Name this event, which is depicted at the end of Farewell My Concubine, when a Peking opera troupe is subjected to "struggle sessions.” This event is depicted in the "Scar Art" and "Scar Literature" movements.

The Blue Kite and Farewell My Concubine, are films from this country's 5th Generation of filmmaking, which frequently depicted events from this country's history, including the Cultural Revolution and Great Leap Forward.
This other 5th generation film by Zhang Yimou depicts the death of Xu Fugui's daughter, Fengxia, from childbirth complications. This film shares its name with the Yu Hua novel on which it is based.
